etymologies: Middle English (denoting a regulation requiring people to extinguish fires at a fixed hour in the evening, or a bell rung at that hour): from Old French cuevrefeu, from cuvrir ‘to cover’ + feu ‘fire’. The current sense dates from the late 19th century

definitions: a regulation requiring people to remain indoors between specified hours, typically at night

examples.text: the whole area was immediately placed under curfew

shortDefinitions: regulation requiring people to remain indoors between specified hours

definitions: the hour designated as the beginning of a curfew

examples.text: to be out after curfew without permission was to risk punishment

shortDefinitions: hour designated as beginning of curfew

definitions: a daily signal indicating the start of curfew

examples.text: they had to return before the curfew sounded
